evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical evidence (H1-H4) directly documents the pushback event, including the procedural deviation where the aircraft moved beyond the Tug release point and hit the blast barrier, confirming observation and documentation during the preliminary review.

node.statement: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations, including timing, communication protocols, and adherence to standard operating procedures for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

assumptions: Standard operating procedures include stopping at the TRP and communication via interphone
The instructor's actions represent adherence to SOPs
defeaters: Evidence showing explicit violation of communication protocols or SOPs
Evidence that the deviation was due to factors outside timing, communication, or SOP adherence

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication protocols were followed (H1), a procedural decision to swap drivers occurred (H2), and the instructor corrected the pushback path (H3), but the aircraft still passed the TRP and hit a barrier (H4), indicating partial adherence to procedures but a deviation in timing or execution.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit SOP documentation or timing standards provided; ambiguity in whether the deviation fully aligns with key features

node.statement: The identified procedural deviation withstands potential defeaters as it is corroborated by multiple sources and consistent with operational data from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The history items accurately represent the event timeline and roles
No other conflicting evidence exists outside the provided items
defeaters: Additional contradictory operational data or eyewitness accounts
Evidence showing procedural compliance or alternative explanations for the event
